CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is an active officer of the NORP navy , third rank captain . He was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was involved in a dispute with his employer , ORG of GPE , concerning the amount of compensation of his travel expenses . On DATE the ORG awarded him arrears in the amount of MONEY ( RUR ) and RUR CARDINAL in compensation of legal expenses . This decision was not appealed against and on DATE became final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court issued a writ of execution . The applicant forwarded it with accompanying documents to the ORG treasury office . On DATE the writ was returned to the applicant unexecuted . The treasury office explained that the debtor had no available funds which could be used for paying the judgment debt . The applicant was advised to address the writ of execution to the head office of ORG , which the applicant did on DATE . However , the judgment remained unexecuted .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote a new letter to ORG , requesting an explanation as to why the judgment remained unexecuted to that date . On DATE ORG informed the applicant that the writ of execution had been transmitted to ORG with a view to prepare a budget call for the respective amount . They also informed the applicant that ORG had no power to enforce the judgment and write off the money from the accounts of ORG without their acceptance .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG transferred to the applicant RUR CARDINAL with reference to the arrears due pursuant to the judgment of DATE . On DATE the applicant received the rest of the amount awarded by the court ( RUR CARDINAL ) .
